newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.African platinum mine calm after ethnic feuding.
newsitem.headline: S.African platinum mine calm after ethnic feuding.

text.p: South Africa's largest miners' union vowed on Monday to track down the culprits responsible for ethnic clashes in which at least 37 blacks were killed at or near a platinum mine north-west of Johannesburg at the weekend.
The National Union of Mineworkers said in a statement it would do all it could to ensure that those behind the violence were brought to book.
"We will leave no stone unturned in finding out who are the perpetrators of the violence," said NUM deputy secretary Gwede Mantashe.
If any NUM member was found to have been involved, they would face disciplinary action and possibly lose their union membership, Mantashe added.
Police said fighting between members of different tribes broke out on Saturday morning at a squatter camp called Freedom Park near the Wildebeesfontein mine in Rustenburg.
The clashes, between members of the Sotho and Xhosa tribes, spread to a hostel for migrant workers at the mine, owned by Impala Platinum Holdings.
Army troops and policemen moved in on Sunday to patrol the area and to prevent further clashes. Police spokeswoman Captain Belinda Kleynhans said the violence appeared to have subsided.
"The situation is very quiet now. From yesterday (Sunday) afternoon and evening there have been no further incidents," Kleynhans told Reuters.
She said around 200 policemen and 50 soldiers were on the ground and if no further conflicts arose some could be pulled out by Monday afternoon.

South Africa's mining industry is built on a labour system under which men leave their wives and families for months at a time to work on the mines. Mine hostels are largely segregated on ethnic lines.
